title: My husband and I are being sued by a creditor (Fedex) Is their a special form require by the court to answer the summons?
question: Superior court of California county of Riverside demand $30,297.56
question_tags: LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Sued for debt
answers:
The short answer is no. Most often it seems defendant's representing themselves use form PLD-050 from the California Judicial Council to respond to a Complaint. However, depending on the facts of your case, the way the Complaint is drafted, whether or not the Complaint is verified, etc., you may not wish to simply generally deny the allegations contained therein.

In any event, the law limits the amount of time you have to respond. You must act quickly.

Good luck.

You should hire a local lawyer to defend you in the case. Generally speaking, once defendants are personally served with the Summons & Complaint, the defendants have 30 days to file responsive pleadings to the Complaint. The time limit is specified on the Summons itself. The responsive pleadings vary and may include Motions to Quash, Demurrers, Motions to Strike, Answers, or various other pleadings. An individual may represent themselves. A corporation, LLC or related organization would need to be represented by counsel. If you are individuals and choose to represented yourselves, you are held to the same standards as a licensed attorney at law.

It is not the "Summons" that requires an answer, but rather the petition .
You are in over your head and need a lawyer.

Please don't try to defend a $30,000 case by yourself. Spend the small amount to hire an attorney to defend you. There are so many ways that a case can go wrong, that it's penny-wise but pound-foolish to consider defending yourself.

You can find attorneys here on Avvo who de credit defense, or go to the National Association of Consumer Advocates http://www.naca.net
For $30,000 I think you should consult a lawyer who can prepare a defense for you.
